abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is unsatisfactory,
            sustainability unlikely, and the institutional development
            impact negligible. Regrettably, both performances by the
            Bank, and Borrower are rated unsatisfactory, given
            insufficient precautions to ensure implementation readiness,
            and, granting credit effectiveness before the
            Borrower's meeting the agreed conditionality, i.e., the
            creation of a consortium of private oil companies. Key
            lessons focus on: 1) project preparation and appraisal,
            suggesting that leaving a critical part of the petroleum
            supply chain, the Indeni Refinery, outside the scope of the
            project, contributed to delays in the technical evaluation
            of the pipeline, and to Tazama's financial problems.
            Furthermore, if implementation progress depends on key
            actions of private sector companies that are not parties to
            the project, it is paramount that these actions take place
            prior to Board Approval, emphasizing the fact that inclusion
            of private oil marketing companies as project beneficiaries,
            improves both implementation, and development objectives.
            Also, a comprehensive risk assessment should be contingent
            to a petroleum sector project requiring major institutional
            changes; and, 2) project supervision, highlighting the
            importance of minimizing effectiveness issues, which could
            have avoided delays of the investment components, and, the
            need to incorporate the Borrower's views into the
            reporting system, to enhance ownership, and, include as
            well, a solid policy dialogue, as part of the Bank's
            overall macroeconomic framework.
